intro: Salpichroa diffusa var. longiflora, commonly known as the long-flowered sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous perennial with slender, creeping stems that root at the nodes. The plant produces small, pale blue to violet flowers arranged in spikes, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped, hairy, and often covered in fine white pubescence. It thrives in well-drained sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes.
